comments.commentBody:
If this alarming example of Big Brothering doesn't make the champions of "disruptive" business practices reconsider their enthusiasm for companies such as Uber, what will?

Instead of pouring money into ways of evading the law, Uber should be setting up a fund to buy out the very costly taxi medallions that Uber has made worthless.

How was this entrapment? The system was operating illegally in Portland. All the code enforcement people were doing was ordering up a ride to prove it so. Same with undercover police buying illegal guns and arresting perpetrators or making drug purchase... If not the police, there are plenty of other real customers doing the drug and gun buys. The dealers were doing their deeds in any case.

Ditto with UBER. If it had not been the code enforcers calling and being thwarted by questionable means by UBER, it would have been, and was, other customers calling and the rides would have been and were provided.

I don't take taxies much, but whenever I have, it is disheartening to know that the cab driver is somehow cheating you with some odd trick up his sleeve to milk you off a few dollars. The money is not that important as the thought of getting cheated. Uber with all its flaws somehow does not leave you with that feeling. There is always room for improvement and I sincerely hope Uber changes it corporate culture. Cab drivers on the other hand need to step up to the plate and be more helpful and honest. Otherwise they will suffer the same fate as telephone operators and typists.
They are just like scabs and I don't cross picket lines, even invisible ones. Ever.
I use uber. I always talk to drivers. They have few of any complaints. Get over yourself.

Good question, David.
Personal auto liability policies exclude your car "if used as a livery or taxi."
Here in the D.C. area, and, I presume, elsewhere, Uber purchases insurance to cover its drivers for liability. I just settled a claim with them.
They made a fake app in part to use for people who are a danger to drivers, rather than simply ban them. Please.

am I missing something?  Where is it written that taxi and livery services are supposed to have a monopoly on service areas?  In a capitalistic economy isn't the delivery of quality  goods and services, at an agreed upon price, with a ROI for the shareholder the driving principals?  Like all things in nature, you adapt or die.
Social Darwinism reaches out from its 20th century tomb to frighten us once again. Please, drive a stake through its heart to prevent the seduction of yet another generation
Deregulation is a race to the top. In a free competition customers will choose the best.

Gosh, I'm glad I have a more protective spouse. Suppose your wife is robbed or raped. How would she describe the perpetrator to the police?

Most cities have special vans for the disabled who need public transportation. It's even cheaper than Uber would be!

"If Uber is looking up credit card information of potential riders ( in this case law enforcement) in order to categorize them and deny them service,"

If one offers to pay with a credit card then Uber has a right to check into that credit card.
" imagine what Uber is doing with everyone else's personal and financial information. "
Probably determining whether or not the credit card is valid.
If they check your credit history or ratings you can determine that.
Repeated instances sexual harassment internally, blatant violations of law, and now this, a clear conspiracy to evade law enforcement?  Last straw.  Uber app deleted.
The city government of Portland is all about control, not protection. They hate free enterprise like the Uber business model,where they are not the middlemen.

Arthur Andersen, Enron and others have found out the hard way that a company that adopts a systemic culture of lawlessness can't survive long-term. If Uber is indeed knowing building a culture that violates laws it too shall be labelled a criminal enterprise and won't last.

State IRA plans are a bad idea. We know that by the way state 529s work.

The 529 is a way to save for college and get federal and state tax breaks. But each state only allows state tax breaks from those 529 program that it sanctions. Sanctioning means the state got some kind of kick back from the program.

That means that people who move or expect to move from one state to another are at a disadvantage. They stop receiving the state tax benefit of their 529 by moving to another state. At the very least this means opening and managing numerous 529 accounts each time they move. The state sanctioned accounts are usually managed by companies with clunky websites and high fees.

The saving for retirement should be separate from taking a federal or state tax deduction. Anyone who saves for retirement through any program should be eligible the full tax benefits. It is unfair and inefficient to deny some people the tax benefits and force them into complicated savings programs.
How many countries that have nuclear weapons were invaded or lost a war ?
No one knew North Korean cyber warfare was so complicated.
given this administration probably better
Oh please. It is not a "fear" of normalizing our disgustingly bigoted President – it is the reality of it. He is not capable of leading this country in peace time, let alone during a crisis.

Just like Sanger outed the NSA surveillance of domestic phone and internet more than a decade ago.  Treason is not too strong a word.  Aid and comfort to the North Koreans by giving them a nice, Korean-language account on the front page of how the Pentagon broke U.S. and international laws.  David Sanger, meet Jefferson Sessions.

...first it was Saddam Hussein, the biggest threat to world peace, and now apparently North Korea.
Unfortunately the NY Times on more than one occasions acted nothing nothing more than a propagandist outreach arm of the Pentagon and all the war mongers around it, for this to masquerade as journalism.
The American public clueless as always will just hand over the money no questions asked (there's really no public debate , different opinions, or opposition, when it comes to anything geopolitical..)

With a thin skinned, trigger happy clueless President at the top, the US and the World has become a much more dangerous place indeed...

Plennnie it must be nice sitting in Switzerland, a country with no military or defense mechanisms, throwing stones at the world's protector.  Don't think for a moment that Kim Jong-un wouldn't flip that switch.  I'm sure you're aware that he just had is half brother killed last week, his uncle last year and hundreds of other people since he came into power.  He'll use his nuclear capability to hold the rest of the world hostage if we don't step in and stop him.
Why don't we explode an ICBM over their capital that showers the royal palace with flowers, mushrooms and weed. Just for kicks.
After watching the excellent documentary Zero Days, I now look for articles by David Sanger– extraordinary reporting.
Trump's missile is bigger.   He said so during his election.
